24536373.trustfund: TFM23656-RURAL TRANSPORT PROJECT II,TFS23656-RURAL TRANSPORT PROJECT II,TF025576-PHRD-SECOND RURAL TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF034859-VIETNAM - RURAL TRANSPORT PROJECT,VIETNAM - RURAL TRANSPORT II PROJECT,TF023656-RURAL TRANSPORT PROJECT II

0.cdata!: Las carreteras transitables facilitan el desarrollo

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Transport Project (RT2)
            of Vietnam had the following ratings: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. The lessons learned included: 1)
            The key procurement lesson learnt from RT2 is the need to
            support Vietnam's development and adherence to a modern
            competitive procurement practice, one that leads to
            transparency and accountability; 2) Future operations should
            adopt a more flexible approach, based on improved national
            standards, to provide greater technical guidance to
            provinces on standards and surface specification. Further
            work also needs to be done to monitor the trials and
            complete the economic analysis to support these decisions
            and undertake trials in the three remaining geographic areas
            of Vietnam; 3) Institutional development can only be
            effective when based on a sound analysis of the
            institutional mandates, incentives and capacity of the
            agencies responsible for rural transport in Vietnam; 4) The
            long term international consultants had limited impact due
            to their central location and a lack of local knowledge and
            language skills. Future projects should rely more on local
            consultants based regionally; 5) Based on RT2 experience a
            network approach to maintenance should be adopted that
            provides provinces with clear incentives to increase
            recurrent financing to ensure sufficient maintenance
            funding; and 6) The development of the private sector was
            particularly successful primarily because it focused on
            providing a market for small-scale contractors. This
            approach should be continued in future.
